BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northwesterly wind, dangerous wind slabs formed above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep northeast, east and southeast facing slopes. Avalanches can in some places be released in near-ground layers, mostly by large additional loads.
As the temperature drops individual avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.
Weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Some snow will fall over a wide area. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger. This applies above approximately 2400 m. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, caution is to be exercised in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation on the Main Alpine Ridge. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.

As a consequence of a sometimes strong southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas at elevated altitudes. The prevalence of such avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can in isolated cases reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in some localities. The meteorological conditions will foster a stabilisation of the snowpack. In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar, especially in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation on the Main Alpine Ridge. Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.

Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. The new snow and wind slabs of Wednesday can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and snow slides being released will increase on very steep slopes below approximately 1400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Natural avalanches are possible in particular on steep slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1800 m. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, snow drift accumulations formed. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes strong northwesterly wind, wind slabs formed in particular above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep northeast, east and southeast facing slopes. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Avalanches can to some extent be released in the weakly bonded old snow, even by small loads in isolated cases.
The natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease. Some medium-sized natural avalanches are, however, not entirely ruled out.
Above the tree line a dangerous avalanche situation will persist. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in some places. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger, especially above approximately 2400 m. Old wind slabs require caution. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.

As a consequence of a sometimes strong southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas at elevated altitudes. The prevalence of such avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m. In some places new snow is lying on surface hoar. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be severely restricted. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall in some localities. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northwesterly wind, dangerous wind slabs formed above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep northeast, east and southeast facing slopes above approximately 2200 m.
As the temperature drops individual avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.
Weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Some snow will fall over a wide area. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northwesterly wind, dangerous wind slabs formed above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. The wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep northeast, east and southeast facing slopes above approximately 2200 m.
As the temperature drops individual avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.
Weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Some snow will fall over a wide area. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In high Alpine regions a dangerous avalanche situation will be encountered in some regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the northerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on northwest to east to southeast facing aspects and generally in high Alpine regions.
The fresh wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In high Alpine regions a dangerous avalanche situation will be encountered in some regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the northerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on northwest to east to southeast facing aspects and generally in high Alpine regions.
The fresh wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines.

The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall over a wide area. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften quickly. Individual, then as the precipitation becomes heavier more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and snowfall the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

The new snow and wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The meteorological conditions will foster a stabilisation of the snowpack. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.

Some snow will fall in some localities. The wind will be moderate to strong in some localities. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding snow represents the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northerly directions, wind slabs formed on Wednesday in particular adjacent to ridgelines. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m.
These places are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Several medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
The weather conditions facilitated a gradual strengthening of the near-surface layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow will fall in the evening above approximately 1300 m.
The wind has transported some snow.
Large wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days, in particular on sunny slopes.
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 160 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
New snow:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs of Wednesday can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. The wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads in particular. The wind slabs of the last few days are to be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above the tree line. These are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are small.
On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be severely restricted. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall in some localities. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On Wednesday the wind was moderate to strong in particular along the border with Switzerland and along the border with France.
As a consequence of wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs formed. They are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2400 m, in particular on very steep slopes.
These places are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow will fall in the evening above approximately 1300 m.
The northwesterly wind has transported some snow.
The snowpack is weak in some cases, in particular on shady slopes.
As a consequence of solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Some new snow:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow is to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before. Also in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack above approximately 1900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.
